Hero.title:
Judged and Called by System,
Real-time Integrated Management System
Hero.description:
We wanted to reduce the meaningless wasted time in complex examination processes.
By switching from human intuition to algorithms for order assignment, we reduced unnecessary waiting time by over 1 hour daily.

BusinessContext.title: What is the Cohort Project?
BusinessContext.description: A large-scale health checkup project where 10 researchers conduct 5+ examinations for 15~20 participants within a limited time daily.
BusinessContext.problemDesc: Proceeding in A→B→C order caused long lines at specific stations while others were empty. Assistants were confused trying to find the next participant from piled charts whenever a station became free.
BusinessContext.solutionDesc: "First arrived, first available test" — We envisioned a flexible first-come-first-served system. When a station opens, the system automatically calls the next participant to minimize waiting time.

Bottleneck.title: Optimizing Exam Flow
Bottleneck.description:
Abandoned the 'Single Line' method where you wait for the person ahead,
and introduced 'Real-time Assignment' to guide people to empty rooms immediately.

before.title: Legacy System
before.subtitle: Single Line (Bottleneck)
problems: Cannot enter until Dementia Screening (60m) finishes
Start delayed even if front exams are fast
Empty rooms unusable due to fixed order

after.title: New System
after.subtitle: Priority Assignment to Empty Slots
solutions: Strict arrival order (FIFO) to prevent complaints

results.time: Result 1: Reduced total operation time by over 1 hour (Daily)
results.satisfaction: Result 2: Reduced complaints & fatigue via real-time assignment

TechStack.title: Data Flow & Architecture
TechStack.description:
Uses familiar tools (Google Sheets) as DB,
combining Firebase (Cloud DB) and Apps Script for real-time performance.

appsheet.label: On-site Input (Tablet)
appsheet.title: Tablet Reception System
appsheet.desc: No more complex paper forms. Just a few touches on a tablet. Easy for both seniors and researchers.

sheets.label: Google Sheets (DB)
sheets.title: Familiar Excel (Google Sheets)
sheets.desc: We didn't use expensive DBs. Leverage Excel that researchers are most familiar with, reducing training costs to zero.

appsscript.label: Apps Script (Logic)
appsscript.title: Smart Traffic Control (Algorithm)
appsscript.desc: As soon as 'Exam Complete' is pressed, the system recognizes empty seats and calls the next candidate. No more shouting to find people.

firebase.label: Firebase (Real-time)
firebase.title: Firebase: Trigger-based Real-time Sync
firebase.desc: Data changes in Apps Script trigger a push to Firebase Realtime Database. Stable real-time sync with just cloud services (Apps Script & Firebase) without a dedicated server.

dashboard.label: Web Dashboard
dashboard.title: Voice Assistant
dashboard.desc: When the voice says 'Mr. Kim, your next exam is ECG', assistants recognize the participant and guide them immediately.

Logic.title:
"Zero Human Error"
Optimal Flow
Logic.description:
Field operations are complex. The system aggregates real-time data
to select the most efficient and fair next candidate.

1.title: 1. Check Availability
1.desc: Exclude those currently testing or already finished.

2.title: 2. Check Prerequisites
2.desc: Ex: ECG is only available after 'Body Function' is complete.

3.title: 3. Assign by Arrival (FIFO)
3.desc: Prioritize the earliest arrival among remaining candidates.

4.title: 4. Text-To-Speech (Auto-Call)
4.desc: Automatically calls the target via Google TTS service.

LogicFlow.ttsMessage: {name}, your next exam is {room}.

Insight.title: Record of Thoughts for a Better System
Insight.description:
Beyond technical implementation, this contains practical concerns faced on-site
and insights gained while solving them.

speed.title: Technology ignoring on-site speed was not the answer
speed.content: I thought it was logically flawless. But for researchers, the 'Complete' button was just an annoying extra task. They didn't sympathize with how critical that data was for clearing the queue, so they often forgot to press it. I learned the hard way that the technological answer is not always the on-site solution.

empathy.title: Gaining user empathy was more important than features
empathy.content: I went to the field before fixing code. I explained 'why this system is needed' and shared the goal that it's a 'tool to increase participant satisfaction and minimize human error', not just a work order. Once users understood the system's value and felt like colleagues, complex exceptions started to be resolved with their willing cooperation.

trust.title: Technology is complete only with user trust
trust.content: As trust built up, a virtuous cycle of data occurred. Missing inputs disappeared, the algorithm functioned properly, and the morning bottlenecks resolved naturally. I learned the essential value that system efficiency is proportional to user trust, not algorithm performance.

ExamFlow.title: Real-time Sync: Tablet → Board → TTS
ExamFlow.description: This simulates the process where pressing "Complete" on a tablet instantly updates the status board and triggers the automated voice guidance system.
